titleStmt.title: Generalized State Estimation for Markovian Coupled Networks Under Round-Robin Protocol and Redundant Channels

analytic.title: Generalized State Estimation for Markovian Coupled Networks Under Round-Robin Protocol and Redundant Channels

biblStruct.note: Manuscript received May 9, 2017; revised October 17, 2017 and January 12, 2018; accepted January 26, 2018.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, the problem of generalized state estimation for an array of Markovian coupled networks under the round-Robin protocol (RRP) and redundant channels is investigated by using an extended dissipative property. The randomly varying coupling of the networks under consideration is governed by a Markov chain. With the aid of using the RRP, the transmission order of nodes is availably orchestrated. In this case, the probability of occurrence data collisions through a shared constrained network may be reduced. The redundant channels are also used in the signal transmission to deal with the frangibility of networks caused by a single channel in the networks. The network induced phenomena, that is, randomly occurring packet dropouts and randomly occurring quantization are fully considered. The main purpose of the research is to find a desired estimator design approach such that the extended ( 1 , 2 , 3 ) -γ -stochastic dissipativity property of the estimation error system is guaranteed. In terms of the Lyapunov-Krasovskii methodology, the Kronecker product and an improved matrix decoupling approach, sufficient conditions for such an addressed problem are established by means of handling some convex optimization problems. Finally, the serviceability of the proposed method is explained by providing an illustrated example.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: C OMPLEX coupled networks (CCNs), which can be described by a series of nodes and appropriately coupled matrices, have been successfully applied in many practical fields, including smart power grids, mobile manipulators, social interactions, metabolic networks, biological neural networks, and so on [1]- [4]. Hence, an enormous amount of research has been emphatically contributed to the discussions on CCNs during the last decades [5]- [11]. In these works, the coupling connection topology (CCT) of CCNs is invariant. However, as pointed out in [12], under some undesirable networked environments, compared with such a constant CCT, the time-varying CCT is more realistic relying on the fact that the implemented CCT in practice often varies according to the different situations [13]. Sometimes, the changes of CCT for CCNs are randomly occurring and obey the Markov process. In this regard, such CCNs are referred to as the Markovian coupled networks (MCNs). Recently, more and more research attentions have been concentrated on the dynamic analysis problems for MCNs, including, but are not limited to, synchronization, stability and stabilization, target control [14]- [18], and the references therein.

In another research direction, state estimation serves as a significant role in the research of CCNs, and one of the main purposes of which is to accurately obtain state information of CCNs limited by prescribed property requirements [19]. As a result, the past few decades have seen a great amount of interests on this fundamental research issue [20], [21]. It is generally acceptable that the objective of such an issue is to construct an estimator with compatible structure, where the network system state is estimated based on the available measurements. Up to now, considerable achievements concerning multiple state estimation problems for CCNs have been studied in the outstanding literature. For instance, the recursive state estimation issue through a variance-constrained method has been introduced for time-varying CCNs with missing measurements which are modeled by a group of stochastic variables according with the prescribed probabilistic distributions in [22]. Recently, due to increasing research interests in the resulting error system satisfying certain performance index, a battery of worth mentioning and crucial state estimation methods have been proposed, for instance, dissipative state estimation [23], [24], passive state estimation [25], H ∞ state estimation [26], l 2l ∞ state estimation [27].
2168-2267 c 2018 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

Along with networked systems have developed rapidly, the complexity of tasks generated by networked systems to be accomplished is increasing, and the number of data from the networks inclines to be enormous. These phenomena have brought a large number of burden to the networks of communication capacity constraint, which could give rise to some network-induced problems, in particular data collisions and disorder. Therefore, how to prevent and maintain signal transmissions from these network-induced phenomena is an interesting question. In this regard, signal communication naturally becomes a critical element in the study of networked systems [28], [29]. The common point of these studies is to utilize an effective approach which schedules the signal transmissions in the light of certain network protocol. In view of this, the round-Robin protocol (RRP) may be a good candidate. RRP is one of the most well-known periodic mechanisms which has been widely applied to network communication and allocation of server resources. For example, the problem of distributed state estimation subject to finite-time boundedness, RRP and fading channels has been studied in [30], in which RRP was taken into account to overcome the limited bandwidth of networks, and channels fading is modeled by a set of multiplicative noises. Zou et al. [31] have concerned the state estimation issue for CCNs subject to time-varying delays and disturbances under the RRP, which was utilized to coordinate the nodes transmission order.

As a fundamental problem in applications over CCNs, the issues of reliability for data transmission have been recurrently investigated in literatures over the last few decades. Since one channel is modeled by fluctuating performance that is affected by sudden environmental changes or unavoidable system failures. Therefore, the redundant channel communication scheme has potential advantages in the improvement of communication reliability in modern industry, and it has been applied in networked control and state estimation problems in [32]. Under redundant channel communication scheme, it is preferable to overcome the fragility of communication networks commonly configured by a single channel. In this case, in [33], the distributed H ∞ filtering issue for T-S fuzzy systems has been considered, where the time-varying delays have been studied and the sensor nodes have been added with redundant channels.

In response to the above considerations, our focuses are devoted to the extended dissipative estimation issue for MCNs under the RRP and redundant channels by designing a desired type of estimator in this paper. The main advantages of this paper are four aspects as follows.

1) Directed at a class of MCNs, we investigate the extended dissipative estimation, which could be used to cope with many estimation issues including standard dissipative estimation, l 2l ∞ estimation, H ∞ estimation, and passive estimation. Consequently, a more general issue is taken into account. 2) A Markov chain is used to show the randomly varying coupled condition which is affected by external disturbances.

3) The transmission order of nodes is availably orchestrated with the aid of the commendable use of the RRP. In this case, at each time instant, only one node is allowed to transmit data through a shared constrained network. 4) The redundant channels are used in the signal transmission to deal with the frangibility of communication networks caused by a single channel in the networks. This paper is organized as follows. The dynamic of coupled networks and networked constrained measurements are described in Section II. The study of the analysis and design of extended dissipative state estimator for the considered MCNs is carried out in Section III. A trustworthy example is given to validate the serviceability of our given approach in Section IV. This paper is finally concluded in Section V.

Notation: The notation employed in this paper is standard. The a-dimensional Euclidean space is denoted as R a . The notation R a×b represents the set of all a × b real matrices. The superscripts " * " and "T" indicate symmetric entry and the transpose, respectively. And for matrix , the notation > 0 (respectively, ≥ 0) implies that such a matrix is symmetric positive definite (respectively, symmetric positive semi-definite). l 2 [0, ∞) denotes the space of square summable infinite sequence. I stands for the appropriate dimensional identity matrix. 0 represents appropriate dimensional zero matrix. δ(b) is a binary function which equals to 1 (respectively, 0) when b = 0 (respectively, b = 0). The diagonal matrix is denoted as diag{•}. E{•} denotes the mathematical expectation. Matrices are supposed to have compatible dimensions if not explicitly stated. The set of non-negative integers here is described as Z + .

div.head: A. Dynamic of Coupled Networks
div.p: Let us pay close attention to the following dynamical network represented by a stochastic discrete-time MCNs composing of N coupled nodes:
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ x i (k + 1) = f (x i (k)) + N j=1 ijσ (k) σ (k) x j (k) + E i υ(k) z i (k) = L i x i (k) (1)
div.p: for i ∈ N {1, 2, . . . , N}, where x i (k) ∈ R n stands for the state vector of the ith node. The output vector to be estimated for the ith node is described as z i (k) ∈ R m . υ(k) ∈ R p denotes the exogenous disturbance that belongs to l 2 [0, ∞). E i and L i are real constant appropriate dimensional system matrices. The nonlinear vector-valued function f (•) satisfies the sectorbounded condition in the following form [31]:
where f (0) = 0, ∀τ 1 , τ 2 ∈ R n , 1 and 2 are constant real appropriate dimensional matrices. In this paper, a jumping directed graph Js
div.formula: σ (k) = (Y, T σ (k) , W σ (k) ) is utilized to represent the outer-coupling conditions, where Y {r 1 , r 2 , . . . , r N } denotes the set of nodes, T σ (k) ∈ Y × Y are sets of edge, and W σ (k) { ijσ (k) } ∈ R N×N are outer-coupling matrices, in which
π κ Pr{σ (k + 1) = |σ (k) = κ } where 0 ≤ π κ ≤ 1, ∀κ, ∈ M,
div.p: and
div.formula: M =1 π κ = 1, ∀κ ∈ M. Inner-coupling matrices σ (k) = diag{v 1σ (k) , v 2σ (k) , . . . , v Nσ (k) } ≥ 0 link the jth state variable if v jσ (k) = 0.
div.p: Remark 1: The coupling conditions, in practical applications, are often influenced by the external disturbances that have influences on the stability and the performance of coupled networks. Since the structure of coupled networks is modeled by coupling matrices, in order to accurately investigate CCNs, it is incontrovertible that the randomly varying coupling becomes a significative research direction. In this paper, a Markov stochastic process has been applied to describe the outer-coupling and inner-coupling matrices which can stochastically shift or jump from one mode to another during different time intervals [34]- [36].

div.head: B. Networked Constrained Measurements
div.p: Throughout this paper, the measurement output y i (k) of the MCNs (1) received from the plant through two different channels which are chosen in a random way and both are quantized, is described by
div.formula: y i (k) = α i (k)(C i Q 1 (x i (k)) + D i υ(k)) + (1 -α i (k)) × β i (k)(F i Q 2 (x i (k)) + G i υ(k))(3)
div.p: where y i (k) ∈ R q is the measured output. The matrices C i , D i , F i , and G i are real constant appropriate dimensional matrices.
div.formula: Q 1 (•) and Q 2 (•) represent the quantization effects, the following logarithmic quantizer Q h (•), h ∈ {1, 2}, is considered [24]: Q h (x i (k)) = q h1 (x i1 (k)) • • • q hn (x in (k)) T .
div.p: For each q hl (x il (k)), l ∈ {1, 2, . . . , n}, we obtain the following set of quantization levels:

where 0 < μ hl < 1 is used to describe the quantization density and ū(0) hl > 0 stands for a segment of the input of quantizer so as to that the whole segment is mapped to such a quantization level by the quantizer. The notation q hl (•) for the logarithmic quantizer is represented in the following form: where
div.formula: q hl (x il (k)) ⎧ ⎨ ⎩ ū(n) hl , 1 1+ζ hl ū(n) hl < x il (k) ≤ 1 1-ζ hl ū(n) hl 0, x il (k) = 0 q hl (-x il (k)), x il (k) < 0 (4)
ζ hl = (1 -μ hl )/(1 + μ hl ).
div.p: Inspired by [37], using the sector bound approach, the quantization problem can be transformed into the robust problem without conservatism. Then, we obtain
with
div.formula: | hi (k)| ≤ ζ hl for each l ∈ {1, 2, . . . , n}.
div.p: Two Bernoulli distributed white sequences α i (k) and β i (k) are mutually independent and take values 0 or 1, which are used to model both randomly occurring packet dropouts and quantization in two channels, respectively. Particularly, they are explicitly stated by the probability distribution laws in the following:
div.formula: Pr{α i (k) = 1} = E{α i (k)} = ᾱi Pr{β i (k) = 1} = E{β i (k)} = βi(6)
div.p: where the scalars ᾱi ∈ [0, 1] and βi ∈ [0, 1] are known.
Clearly, for the Bernoulli distributed white sequences α i (k) and β i (k), one has
div.formula: E{α i (k) -ᾱi } = 0, E |α i (k) -ᾱi | 2 = ᾱi (1 -ᾱi ) E β i (k) -βi = 0, E |β i (k) -βi | 2 = βi 1 -βi .
div.p: Remark 2: As we all know, the signal transmission of single channel may be intermittently interrupted due to its fragility and poor anti-interference capacity, which inevitably increases the packet dropout rate of the communication network. Hence, one redundant channel is used to the communication network to lower the possibility of packet dropouts caused by single channel in this paper. So far, few research efforts have been devoted to the issue for MCNs that both of two channels have signal quantization before transmission and the quantization densities of two channels are different.

Remark 3: It is to be observed that the measurement output y i (k) described in (3) provides a more general type to investigate the phenomena of quantization and randomly occurring packet dropouts in two channels. In particular, if
div.formula: α i (k) = 0, β i (k) = 1, or α i (k) = 1,
div.p: only a channel with quantization transmits its information. In the two cases mentioned above, the packet dropouts are not occurred, it is worth noting that as a special case of α i (k) = 0 and β i (k) = 0, two channels are both useless, and the packet dropouts occur.

In this paper, because of the capacity of communication channel constraints, which can be conjectured that only one node is scheduled to send data via the communication channel at each transmission constant so as to avoid data collisions. Under the circumstances, the RRP can be effectively employed to determine which node gets access to the network in a prescribed transmission moment. It should be worth noting that the RRP is a static one, which transmits the packets in a fixed order.

For the sake of problem formulation, the first transmission instant of the ith node is assumed to be i, one could consider that a round has been finished as shown in Fig. 1 when the entire nodes are got the access one after another in a circle. Then, the signal transmissions of measurement outputs subject to the RRP can be described by Fig. 2, in which y i (k), (i ∈ N) means that the ith node's measurement output gets access to the network at time k, let ȳ
div.formula: (k) = [ ȳT 1 (k) • • • ȳT N (k)
div.p: ] T , and ι(k) = mod(k-1, N)+1 means that ι(k)th node obtains access to the communication network.

Remark 4: In the communication fields, the RRP is always adopted to cut down the network burden and lower the risk of data collisions for its simple structure. Under the RRP, all nodes are transmitted in a particular sequence, and only one node has the authority to send measurement information to the constructed estimator at different transmission instants. Meanwhile, the access permissions will be turned over to the first node after the accomplishment for communication link of last node, we say that a cycle has been completed later.

div.p: In order to accurately estimate the states of the MCNs with an RRP, the state estimator for the MCNs can be constructed as follows:

div.p: Definition 1: For given real matrices 1 = T 1 ≤ 0, 4 = T 4 ≥ 0, 2 , 3 = T 3 = γ 2 I > 0, and a scalar ρ, the estimation error system ( ˜ ) achieves extended stochastic dissipativity, if under zero initial conditions, the following condition holds for any nonzero υ(k) ∈ l 2 [0, ∞):
div.formula: E j k=0 T( 1 , 2 , 3 , k) ≥ ρ sup 0≤k≤j E zT (k) 4 z(k) ∀j > 0 (12
div.p: where

Remark 5: The condition ( 12) can degrade into a standard dissipative property index [17], an l 2l ∞ performance index [38], an H ∞ performance index [18] and a passive property index by tuning ρ, 1 , 2 , 3 , and 4 . The details are given as follows.

1) When setting ρ = 0, the condition ( 12) could turn into a normal dissipative property index if we set that 1 = T 1 ≤ 0 and 3 = T 3 = γ 2 I > 0. 2) When setting ρ = 1, the condition ( 12) can reduce into an l 2l ∞ performance index with the conditions of 3 = T 3 = γ 2 I > 0 and 4 = T 4 ≥ 0. 3) When setting ρ = 0, 2 = 0, the condition ( 12) could degrade into an H ∞ performance index if we set that 1 = T 1 ≤ 0 and 3 = T 3 = γ 2 I > 0. 4) When setting ρ = 0, 1 = 0, the condition ( 12) could transform into a passive property index if we set that 2 = T 2 ≥ 0 and 3 = T 3 = γ 2 I > 0. As a consequence, the condition ( 12) is defined as an extended dissipative property index. Due to the fact that the scalar ρ in ( 12) is introduced, the difficulty of analysis for extended dissipativity in [24] and [38] is reduced from a convenient point of view.

div.head: III. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: In this section, first, the prerequisite sufficient conditions will be presented to ensure that the extended dissipative property of the estimation error system ( ˜ ). Furthermore, the desired estimator gains matrices are designed based on the proposed conditions subject to a set of matrix inequality constraints.

Theorem 1: Let the estimator parameter K κ and scalars ᾱ ∈ [0, 1], β ∈ [0, 1] be given, real matrices 1 = T 1 ≤ 0, 2 , 3 = T 3 = γ 2 I > 0, and 4 = T 4 ≥ 0, the extended stochastic dissipativity property of the estimation error system ( ˜ ) is assured, if there exists a scalar λ > 0 and positive definite matrices P κ,ι(k) > 0, so that the following conditions are satisfied for all κ ∈ M:

div.p: We can easily obtain ¯ κ,ι(k) < 0 by using Schur complement lemma to (13), which implies that
As pointed out in Definition 1, when ρ = 0, the condition (12) corresponds to a ( 1 , 2 , 3 ) -γ -dissipativity property condition. As a consequence, the following condition holds:
under zero initial conditions. Then, it can be verified from (19) that
div.formula: -E j k=0 zT (k) 1 z(k) + 2z T (k) 2 υ(k) + υ T (k) 3 υ(k) ≤ E j k=0 V(e(k), σ (k), ι(k)) -zT (k) 1 z(k) -2z T (k) 2 υ(k) -υ T (k) 3 υ(k) < 0.(20)
div.p: Therefore, the condition ( 12) is satisfied according to ρ = 0. In addition, for the case of ρ = 1, the inequality (12) reduces to an l 2l ∞ performance condition on the basis of Definition 1.
In this circumstance, it is derived based on the condition (18) that for any 0

div.p: Moreover, we can obtain the following inequality in accordance with ( 11) and ( 14):
div.formula: E -e T (k)P κ,ι(k) e(k) + e T (k) LT 4 Le(k) < 0 which implies that E -e T (k)P κ,ι(k) e(k) + zT (k) 4 z(k) < 0.(22)
div.p: Substituting ( 22) into (21), then
div.formula: E zT (k) 4 z(k) < E j k=0 υ T (k) 3 υ(k) .
div.p: Hence, it is readily found that the condition (12) also holds. Finally, one readily validates that the estimation error system ( ˜ ) is extended ( 1 , 2 , 3 )-γ -stochastic dissipative in light of Definition 1. This proof is completed.
In the rest part of this section, the desired estimator gains K κ are designed in (9) on the basis of Theorem 1.

) Proof: Since | h (k)| ≤ ζ hl for each l ∈ {1, 2, . . . , n}, we can obtain T h (k) h (k) ≤ U T h U h ≤ I, h ∈ {1, 2}.

div.p: In the light of ( 26), and by applying in [26, Lemma 1], then pre-and post-multiplying ( 23) by diag{I, I, I, Z -1 κ , Z -1 κ , Z -1 κ , I, I} and its transpose, respectively, according to Schur complement lemma, one could readily find that condition (13) holds. In this regard, we could observe that the extended stochastic dissipativity of the estimation error system ( ˜ ) is achieved. This proof is completed.

div.head: IV. ILLUSTRATED EXAMPLE
div.p: A trustworthy numerical example is introduced in the section to explain the serviceability of the extended dissipative estimator design technique proposed in Theorem 2.
Consider the MCNs represented by (1) with three nodes. Both the outer-coupling and the inner-coupling configuration matrices are random jumping. The outer-coupling matrices have two cases as follows:

Due to the fact that the l 2 -l ∞ state estimation, standard dissipative state estimation, H ∞ state estimation, and passive state estimation issues are a special form of the extended dissipative state estimation issue, we will subsequently focus on two cases in order to verify such a point as follows.

Case 1: l 2 -l ∞ state estimation problem. Under the circumstances, ρ = 1, we designate quantization densities μ 1l = 0.1, μ 2l = 0.8, l ∈ {1, 2}, and set β1 = β2 = β3 = β, ᾱ1 = ᾱ2 = ᾱ3 = ᾱ, 3 = diag{γ 2 , γ 2 , γ 2 }, 4 = diag{1, 1, 1}. In order to ensure that two channels only have the difference of quantization density, other parameters of the measurement output in (3) are taken as
Our aim is to straighten out the impact of ᾱ and β on the l 2l ∞ performance of MCNs for (1) measured by γ min in Table I and Fig. 3.

According to Table I and Fig. 3, we can find two change principles. One is that under ᾱ = 0, it is easy to know that the better optimal l 2l ∞ performance index γ min decreases through increasing value of β, it means that the probability of randomly occurring packet dropouts is smaller, the better performance of the system can be obtained. Meanwhile, the other is that the value of γ min at ᾱ = 1 is worse than ᾱ = 0 and β = 1, which implies that quantization densities μ hl have great influences on the l 2l ∞ performance index γ min of the system.

Case 2: ( 1 , 2 , 3 ) -γ -dissipative state estimation problem. In this case, ρ = 0, we suppose the quantization densities μ 1l = 0.2, μ 2l = 0.7, l ∈ {1, 2}, and let 2 = diag{1, 1, 1}, 1 = -diag{1, 1, 1}, 3 = diag{2, 2, 2}. Other parameters of the measurement output in (3) are chosen as C 1 = 0.5 -0.4 , C 2 = 0.3 0.2 C 3 = 0.4 -0.5 , D 1 = 0.9 0.8 0.6 D 2 = 0.7 0.9 0.8 , D 3 = 0.6 0.8 0.7 F 1 = 0.6 0.4 , F 2 = 0.5 0.3 F 3 = 0.6 0.5 , G 1 = 0.8 0.6 0.9 G 2 = 0.7 0.8 0.6 , G 3 = 0.9 0.7 0.6 .

And the Bernoulli-distributed white noise sequences α i (k)(i = 1, 2, 3) and β i (k) are assumed to satisfy the condition (6) with ᾱ1 = 0.26, ᾱ2 = 0.47, ᾱ3 = 0.76 β1 = 0.48, β2 = 0.27, β3 = 0.82. Under the above obtained estimator gains, the stochastic variable α i (k) is randomly given, as shown in Fig. 4, the state trajectories of zi (k) subject to a possible mode evolution are presented in Fig. 5, where x 1 (0) = [ 0.1 -0.15 ] T , x 2 (0) = [ 0.17 0.1 ] T , x 3 (0) = [ 0.1 -0.2 ] T . The simulation has verified that our theoretical analysis is indeed effective for the addressed extended dissipative state estimation for MCNs subject to the RRP and redundant channels.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: The problem of the extended dissipative estimation for a class of MCNs under the RRP and redundant channels has been investigated in this paper. A novel and more general performance index has been introduced. Based on this, we can conveniently solve l 2l ∞ state estimation, standard dissipative state estimation, passive state estimation, and H ∞ state estimation by changing some parameters. Meanwhile, we have utilized some uncorrelated Bernoulli distributed white sequences to describe both of the quantization and packet dropouts occurred stochastically. By employing a commendable matrix decoupling approach and choosing an advisable Lyapunov function, the solvability of the issue under consideration has been ensured by establishing some available sufficient conditions. A demonstrated example has finally been supplied to the advantages and serviceability of the developed method. It is desired that our method could be employed to deal with the study of the social networks in the statistical physics framework, which will be one of our future research directions.

div.p: This work was supported in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 61304066, Grant 61703004, Grant 61573096, and Grant 61272530, in part by the Natural Science Foundation of Anhui Province under Grant 1708085MF165, in part by the Foundation of Jiangsu Provincial Key Laboratory of Networked Collective Intelligence under Grant BM2017002, and in part by the University Excellent Young Talents Foundation of Anhui Province under Grant gxyqZD2017041. This paper was recommended by Associate Editor R. Selmic.

He is currently a Professor of mathematics with Texas A&M University at Qatar, Doha, Qatar. His current research interests include neural networks, computational intelligence, chaotic dynamical systems, complex networks, and optimization and control.
